title: Prohibits the unsolicited mailing of convenience checks to consumers without the express consent of the consumer
summary: Prohibits the unsolicited mailing of convenience checks to consumers without the express consent of the consumer.
fulltext:
S T A T E   O F   N E W   Y O R K
       ________________________________________________________________________

                                         2995

                              2011-2012 Regular Sessions

                                 I N  A S S E M B L Y

                                   January 21, 2011
                                      ___________

       Introduced by M. of A. MAISEL -- read once and referred to the Committee
         on Consumer Affairs and Protection

       AN ACT to amend the general business law, in relation to prohibiting the
         unsolicited mailing of convenience checks to consumers

         THE  PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section 1. The general business law is amended by adding a new section
    2  520-d to read as follows:
    3    S 520-D. UNSOLICITED CONVENIENCE CHECKS. A. NOTWITHSTANDING ANY  OTHER
    4  PROVISION  OF  LAW, NO ISSUER OR PERSON, FIRM, PARTNERSHIP, ASSOCIATION,
    5  CORPORATION OR AGENT ACTING ON BEHALF OF AN ISSUER, WHETHER OR  NOT  THE
    6  ISSUER  IS  LOCATED  IN  THIS  STATE, SHALL SEND CONVENIENCE CHECKS TO A
    7  CREDIT CARD OR DEBIT CARD HOLDER UNLESS EXPRESS CONSENT  OF  THE  CREDIT
    8  CARD OR DEBIT CARD HOLDER HAS BEEN OBTAINED.
    9    B.  FOR PURPOSES OF THIS SECTION, "CONVENIENCE CHECKS" MEANS ANY NEGO-
   10  TIABLE INSTRUMENT, AS DEFINED BY SECTION 3-104 OF THE UNIFORM COMMERCIAL
   11  CODE, PROVIDED TO A CREDIT CARD OR DEBIT CARD HOLDER BY  A  CREDIT  CARD
   12  ISSUER  OR  PERSON, FIRM, PARTNERSHIP, ASSOCIATION, CORPORATION OR AGENT
   13  ACTING ON BEHALF OF AN ISSUER.
   14    S 2. This act shall take effect immediately.




        EXPLANATION--Matter in ITALICS (underscored) is new; matter in brackets
                             [ ] is old law to be omitted.
                                                                  LBD06410-01-1
